title: Addition
text: Remember that $$f+g$$ is the same as $$\left(f+g\right) x$$. All we have to do is add the two functions.

title: Addition
text: First, because these functions are fractions, we need to find a common denominator. Our common denominator is the product of the two existing denominators: $$(x-4)(6-x)$$.
speech: First, because these functions are fractions, we need to find a common denominator. Our common denominator is the product of the two existing denominators:  times, parentheses x minus 4,  times, parentheses 6 minus x,  .
pacedSpeech: First, because these functions are fractions, we need to find a common denominator. Our common denominator is the product of the two existing denominators:   times,  x minus 4,  times,  6 minus x,

title: Addition
text: Now we need to multiply the fractions by a factor of $$1$$ to get them to have the common denominator. (1/(x-4))*((6-x)(6-x))=(6-x)/((x-4)(6-x), and (1/(6-x))*((x-4)(x-4))=(x-4)/((x-4)(6-x). Now, we need to add these new fractions together.

to get them to have the common denominator. (1/(x-4))*((6-x)(6-x))=(6-x)/((x-4)(6-x), and (1/(6-x))*((x-4)(x-4))=(x-4)/((x-4)(6-x). Now, we need to add these new fractions together.

title: Addition
text: Our last step is to add the numerators. By adding the $$x$$ terms and the constants, $$\frac{x-4+6-x}{\left(x-4\right) \left(6-x\right)}$$ becomes our final solution: $$\frac{2}{\left(x-4\right) \left(6-x\right)}$$.
